comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Low definition monochrome image of highly decorated and distinctively colorful Douglas F4D-1 Skyray Bu No 139164. Of “All Weather Fighter Squadron” VF(AW)-3 with tail code PA and ‘Modex’ 17 on nose. With small ‘NORAD’ badge applied behind cockpit. (North American Air Defense Command) It also carries a dark painted pod on outer wing-see notes below. Color picture of F4D-1 Skyray 139164, unpainted of VF(AW)-3 with tail code PA and ‘Modex’ 22 on nose. Original source unknown: www.millionmonkeytheater.com/f4dpics/139164.jpg Go here for a color profile of an F4D-1 as displayed in the ‘flickr’ pic: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/f/814/3/1/31 Go here for info on the F4D-1: www.joebaugher.com/navy_fighters/f6_2.html (courtesy of Professor Joe Baugher of Chicago, Illinois, USA) Relevant quotes from text; “The first Navy unit to receive Skyrays was Composite Squadron 3 (VC-3) based at NAS Moffett in California, which got its first planes on April 16, 1956. This outfit performed the initial service evaluation of the type. VC-3 was later redesignated VFAW-3, and was attached for a time to the Air Defense Command. While with the ADC, VFAW-3 was based at NAS North Island, San Diego, California. These aircraft participated in the aerial defense of the United States, and carried an electronics package on the fuselage centerline pylon, a pair of 300-gallon underwing drop tanks, a pack of 12 2.75-inch unguided rockets on each of the outer underwing pylons, and a Sidewinder air-to-missile on each of the wing root pylons.” More info on F4D-1 with three pictures of VFAW-3 F4D’s and info on Commanding Officer Eugene Valencia. www.ccdemo.info/AircraftPix/Skyray.html A passage from this webpage illustrates VFAW-3’s role succinctly: www.navalhistory.org/2010/04/29/flightdeck-friday-f4d-sky... NORAD Operations: “The Ford’s interceptor qualities (namely an unmatched climbing ability) were formally recognized when VF(AW)-3 was “chopped” to NORAD for continental defense. Flying out of San Diego, the squadron’s aircraft were painted in one of the better recognized schemes in an era of already colorful Naval aircraft. As the only Navy squadron, VFAW-3 twice won NORAD’s trophy for best performing unit, placing above USAF squadrons in the process. During this time, VFAW-3 was deployed to Key West for the Cuban Missile crisis. That and a deployment to Taiwan in 1958 were the nearest the Ford would get to combat action.” ((Navy slang for the F4D was 'Ford')) F4D-1 139164 was chosen as a subject by Japanese model company “Tamiya” with their 1/48 scale F4D-1 Skyray kit number 61055: www.cybermodeler.com/hobby/kits/tam/kit_tam_61055.shtml www.cybermodeler.com/hobby/kits/tam/images/tam_f4d_decals... F4D-1 139164 was also chosen as a subject by Japanese model company “Tamiya” with their 1/72 scale F4D-1 Skyray kit number 60741: www.hobbywarehouse.com/60741-1-72-F4D-1-Skyray There is as yet no other known internet reference to F4D-1 139164.
